gmx:name.gco:CharacterString: Feature catalog for Quaternary Fault and Fold Database of the United States (Polygons)

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Linear fault features in the conterminous United States.
Internal feature number.
The representation of the entity in the data.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: 1-dimensional element that may or may not surround a 2-dimensional element.
The fault name.
The fault name is unknown.
The fault index number, which is linked to the online fault database.
There is no information about the fault available in the online fault database.
The age of the fault in years.
The fault is less than 1,600,000 years old.
The fault is less than 750,000 years old.
The fault is less than 130,000 years old.
The fault is less than 15,000 years old.
The fault is historic (less than 150 years old.)
Class B faults may or may not be seismogenic (capable of generating earthquakes) and may be older than the Quaternary.
The age is undetermined, but researchers believe that fault motion occurred in the Quaternary.
The rate of motion obtained when the amount of offset is divided by the time interval. It is normalized to millimeters per year.
The rate of motion is less than 0.2 millimeters per year.
The rate of motion is 0.2 to 1 millimeters per year.
The rate of motion is 1 to 5 millimeters per year.
The rate of motion is greater than 5 millimeters per year.
The angle of dip of the fault and the relative direction of movement across the fault.
The angle of dip and the relative direction of movement were not reported in the referenced material for the fault.
Horizontal displacement along a fault such that, in plan view, the side opposite the viewer appears to have moved to the left. This term is also known as sinistral.

A fault characterized by predominantly vertical displacement in which the hanging wall moves downward with respect to the footwall of the fault. If the fault surface is exposed, the footwall is the side onto which water would drip. Generally, this type of fault is a sign of tectonic extension.

A fault in which the displacement is predominantly vertical, and the hanging wall moves up with respect to the footwall. The footwall is the side of the fault onto which water would drip if the fault is exposed.
Horizontal displacement along a fault such that, in plan view, the side opposite the viewer appears to have moved to the right. This term is also known as dextral.

A fault of less than 45 dip in which the displacement is predominantly vertical, and the hanging wall moves up with respect to the footwall. The footwall is the side of the fault onto which water would drip if the fault is exposed.
The general direction of the fault dip which is the angle that the fault is inclined from the horizontal plane.
The direction of the dip is towards the center of a hole or depression, as in a caldera or bowl.
The direction of the dip is toward the east.
The direction of the dip is toward the north.
The direction of the dip is toward the northeast.
The direction of the dip is toward the northwest.
The direction of the dip is toward the south.
The direction of the dip is toward the southeast.
The direction of the dip is toward the southwest.
The direction of the dip is unknown.
The fault face is near vertical.
The direction of the dip is toward the west.

An identification code used to locate data in the online database. This is used by the interactive map service at <http://gldims.cr.usgs.gov/qfault/viewer.htm> and by <http://nationalatlas.gov/mapmaker>
No information about the fault is available in the online database.
Fault feature regions in the conterminous United States.
The representation of the entity in the data.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: 2-dimensional element
The size of the shape in square coverage units. In the distributed file, coverage units represent square decimal degrees.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The perimeter of shape in coverage units. In the distributed file, coverage units represent decimal degrees.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Internal feature number.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The name of the fault region.
A code indicating the age of the faults in years before the present. The code is used for symbolizing the area in the map service and the National Atlas.
The fault age is historic, <150 years - 400 years.
The fault age is Holocene < 15,000 years.
The fault age is late Quaternary < 130,000 years.
The fault age is class B. It is not thought to be seismogenic, and may be older than the Quaternary.
The fault index number(s), which is linked to the online database.
The age of the faults in years before the present.
The faults are less than 1,600,000 years old.
The faults are less than 15,000 years old.
No data are available to determine the fault ages.
Multiple ages were reported.
The rate of motion obtained when the amount of offset is divided by the time interval. It is normalized to millimeters per year.
The rate of motion is less than 0.2 millimeters per year.
The rate of motion is unknown; no data is available.
Not enough data are available to determine the rate of motion.
The angle of dip of the faults and the relative direction of movement across the faults.
No data is available to determine the angle of dip.

A fault characterized by predominantly vertical displacement in which the hanging wall moves downward with respect to the footwall of the fault. If the fault surface is exposed, the footwall is the side onto which water would drip. Generally, this type of fault is a sign of tectonic extension.
Horizontal displacement along a fault such that, in plan view, the side opposite the viewer appears to have moved to the left. This term is also known as left lateral.
Faults are in a combination of dip directions.
The general direction of the fault dip, which is the angle that a fault is inclined from the horizontal plane.
The dips are toward the south and the north.
The dips are toward the southeast and the northwest.
The dips are toward the southwest.
The dips are toward the southwest and the northeast.
The dips are toward the southwest and the vertical.
The direction of the dips is unknown.
The direction of the dips varies.

An identification code used to locate data in the online database. This is used by the interactive map service at <http://gldims.cr.usgs.gov/qfault/viewer.htm> and by <http://nationalatlas.gov/mapmaker>
No information about the fault is available in the online database.
